For a long time in the past, immeasurable eons ago, one has accumulated afflictions and not cultivated good dharmas, therefore one is unable to subdue one's mind for a single day.

It is like a dry bean, no matter how much one pierces it with a needle, it will never stick.
The afflictions are hard and solid, just like this. Even if one focuses the mind and does not let it scatter for a day and night, it is difficult to subdue them.
It is also like a house dog that is not afraid of people, while a wild deer in the mountains and forests runs away in fear upon seeing a person.
Anger is difficult to remove like a house dog, and a compassionate mind is easily lost like that wild deer. Therefore, this mind is difficult to subdue.
For this reason, it is not called great compassion.

It is like a drawing on a stone, its pattern is always there;
A drawing on water quickly disappears, its momentum does not last long.
Anger is like a drawing on a stone, and the roots of all wholesome actions are like that drawing on water. Therefore, this mind is difficult to subdue.
It is like a great mass of fire, its light lasts for a long time;
The light of lightning cannot last for a moment.
Anger is like a mass of fire, and compassion is like the light of lightning. Therefore, this mind is difficult to subdue.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas dwelling in the first ground are called great compassion.

He does not see their faults, and therefore does not give rise to anger.

Removing what is not beneficial for sentient beings is called great kindness;
Desiring to bestow immeasurable benefits and joy upon sentient beings is called great compassion;

Not protecting anything is called great equanimity.
If one does not see self, dharmas, or one's own body, and sees all dharmas as equal and non-dual, this is called great equanimity.

Through the causes and conditions of giving, they enable sentient beings to attain the bliss of peace and comfort, namely food and drink, vehicles, clothing, flowers and incense, bedding and lodging, houses, and lamps.
When making such offerings, the mind is unfettered, free from attachment, and definitely dedicated to supreme, perfect enlightenment.

At that time, the mind has no basis, conceptualization is permanently severed, and one is not frightened, seeking fame, profit, or heavenly bliss, not giving rise to arrogance, not expecting repayment, and not deceiving others. Therefore, one practices giving without seeking wealth and nobility.
When practicing giving, one does not see the recipient as either observing the precepts or violating them, as a field of blessings or not, as a friend or not a friend.

When giving, one does not see them as vessels or not vessels, does not choose the time or place, and also does not consider famine or abundance. One does not see cause and effect, this as a sentient being or not a sentient being, this as merit or not merit.

Although they do not see the giver, the receiver, or the wealth, and do not even see the cutting off [of afflictions] and the fruits and retributions [of actions], they always practice giving without interruption.
Good man!
If bodhisattvas see upholding precepts, breaking precepts, and even fruits and retributions, they will never be able to give.
If one does not practice giving, then one will not be able to perfect the perfection of giving;
if one does not perfect the perfection of giving, then one will not be able to accomplish supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Good man!

It is like a person whose body is struck by a poisonous arrow. The person's relatives wish to bring them peace and remove the poison, so they immediately summon a skilled doctor to pull out the arrow.

Is it human poison?

Such a foolish person in the end is unable to know, and then immediately dies.
Good man!

Bodhisattvas are also like this. If when practicing giving they discriminate the recipient, whether they keep precepts or break precepts, up to the karmic retribution, in the end they are unable to give.

' Good man!

'May all sentient beings attain peaceful and blissful sleep, free from the bed of birth and death, and attain the great parinirvÄá¹‡a, the bed of a lion.

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, with a mind of loving-kindness, give lamps and light, they should always diligently make such vows.
Good man!
All the wholesome roots of Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and buddhas are rooted in kindness.

You should know that this kindness is precisely the TathÄgata.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abiding in the MahÄyÄna MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a cultivate this kind of loving-kindness. Although they are at ease in sleep, they do not sleep, because they are diligent and make energetic progress;

Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
